title: Fisher on lawfulness of slavery - context

content.description:
“If any thing has ever been proved and demonstrated again and again, it is THE LAWFULNESS OF SLAVERY....
It has been proved that the [Latin] maxim, ‘partus sequitur ventrem’ – or that the offspring inherits the status of the parent, is a law of nature, reason, religion, and providence, and that no man has any rights but those to which he is born, or which belong to that condition in which God places him by the hand of his providence....
He that is born a slave, therefore, has no right to liberty, and can acquire none, so long as the right of his master to his service stands in the way.”
Source: Elwood Fisher, Virginia-born, white resident of Cincinnati, Ohio, “Lecture on the North and the South,” delivered in Cincinnati, January 1849
content.question: Which of the following best explains how the concept of partus sequitur ventrem served the interests of enslavers in the United States before the Civil War?

choices.label: It supported enslavers’ claims that legal rights should be based on one’s outward appearance.
It perpetuated slavery over generations and determined the social position of racially mixed offspring.
It enabled enslavers to prohibit the enslaved from gathering and learning to read.
It led enslavers to embrace the notion that race is a social construct.

content.answer: It perpetuated slavery over generations and determined the social position of racially mixed offspring.

topic.text: 2.8: The Social Construction of Race and the Reproduction of Status
